awd_titl_txt: Preparing and diversifying STEM leaders in a first-year to graduation transition program.
awd_abstract_narration:
For this NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM) Capacity Building project, Mills College, a women's college, will improve educational opportunities for low-income, talented women by creating a new transition program to support STEM undergraduate majors from first-year through entry into the workforce or graduate school. A special feature will be on developing leadership skills and tools for women in STEM, thus addressing a gap in the STEM workforce in this arena. The S-STEM Scholars at Mills will receive financial support as well as other support including the expansion of student support systems such as a summer bridge program, targeted faculty advising, a themed housing community, student participation at professional conferences, and specially designed workshops focused on academic and leadership development. To enhance recruiting efforts for minority women, a special Minority Women in STEM Lecture Series will also be deployed.

To study the impact of the STEM leadership for women component and other components of the project, a mixed-method research and evaluation approach will be employed. The project team will measure a number of variables including financial support, student workload, workshop effectiveness, perceived threat level, professional guidance and mentoring, and students' beliefs concerning their intellectual abilities. In addition, formative and longitudinal feedback will be utilized to help determine comprehensive interventions for students who struggle and encounter difficulties in several realms including academics, personal, emotional, and social. The research approach will allow the investigators to measure the success of their strategies, especially when financial burden is lifted via the S-STEM scholarships. The program has been designed to: (1) promote broadening participation in STEM fields; (2) be sustainable at Mills; and (3) be replicable at similar institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF SURPASS (Student Understanding and Realizing Potential for Attaining Scientific Success) Scholarship Program was designed to improve educational opportunities for low-income women and non-gender binary individuals interested in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). This experience incorporated programmatic elements to generate a new, first-year experience through employment or graduate school transition program.

 

The program provided academic, financial, and social support for 14 students to enter and graduate with a degree in one of the STEM majors offered at Mills College. Specifically, the project aimed to graduate 95% from our summer bridge program and retain 80% of students through their first year of study. They were required to maintain an overall GPA of 3.2 or higher, or participate in additional guided mentorship. Program goals included a graduation rate of 80% in STEM degrees and transition at least 70% to careers, or graduate study, in a STEM discipline. The SURPASS program provided financial support, extensive networking, professional development support, and living and learning opportunities for students with both high financial need and an interest in pursuing a STEM degree.

 

Components of the program included workshops and lecture series, a residential learning community focused on mentoring and peer support, an extensive faculty mentoring program in addition to Mills College's traditional close advisor relationships, and opportunities to engage in further professional learning such as tours of area companies or "meet and greets" with women leaders in STEM fields. Mentoring consisted of an intentional faculty-student partnership that was designed to include a minimum of two to four meetings per year. This relationship was formed to support students as a supplement to the traditional advisor-student relationship and to support students in their professional development and career and graduate school planning.

 

Overall, this project funded 19 students, 14 of whom started with our summer bridge program before their first year of college. All 14 of those students entered Mills College, for a 100% retention rate from the summer bridge program. However, 2 students left the institution in the first semester and one student left the institution in their sophomore year. An additional student was disqualified in their junior year for not maintaining the required GPA, even after extensive support over their sophomore year. This student continued to receive support from the program, graduated with a STEM degree, and is employed in a STEM career. Our first to second-year retention of 86% was as expected. We recruited two additional scholars to our first cohort, and 3 additional students as a separate cohort for at least part of their degree program. Therefore, a total of 19 students were supported through this grant.

 

Of the remaining 15 SURPASS Scholars 87% graduated with STEM degrees within four years, with an average GPA of 3.47. The remaining 13% are continuing their studies and we expect, in Spring 2024, that will graduate with STEM degrees, thus yielding a 100% STEM degree graduation rate for our program. The graduates remain committed to pursuing careers in STEM fields. One graduate is pursuing a doctor of medicine and a doctoral research degree, 3 are enrolled in STEM doctoral research degrees, while another has opted for a Master of Science program. Seven graduates have transitioned into STEM careers. Thus, our overall transition rate to graduate programs or careers in STEM currently stands at 92%.

 

Two extreme events took place over the course of this S-STEM grant that demonstrate how strong these results were: 1) The COVID-19 pandemic and the shift to online learning; and 2) the closure of Mills College and its absorption by Northeastern University. Both were extremely disruptive events for students. COVID-19 took what was a program based on building strong relationships, mentoring, and networking for career development and shifted it online. Nationally, for many students, this was a severe disruption for them economically as well as educationally. In a McKinsey report, Cheng, Law, & Pinder (2021) reported that 29% of low-income students dropped out of college during the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, the closure of Mills College as a standalone entity and its absorption by Northeastern University was an extremely disruptive event that occurred during this grant period. Administrative functions were challenged, personnel left the university, and student's academic programs and major requirements were in constant flux. Despite these challenges, our students demonstrated remarkable perseverance. Only three students left the program, after leaving the institution, while the rest completed their STEM degrees within four years (or are still enrolled). Moreover, the majority continue to advance their studies in graduate school in STEM disciplines or pursue STEM careers.


Last Modified: 08/25/2023
Modified by: Helen J Walter
